OVERVIEW: The Redbull series consists of deep, well drained soils that formed in alluvium derived from red calcareous sandstone. Redbull soils are in valleys. Slopes are 3 to 15 percent.  Mean annual precipitation is about 16 inches, and mean annual air temperature is about 44 degrees F.

TAXONOMIC CLASS.content: TAXONOMIC CLASS: Coarse-loamy, mixed, superactive, frigid Aridic Calciustepts

TYPICAL PEDON.content:
TYPICAL PEDON: Redbull silt loam in rangeland, on a northwest facing, 3 percent slope in western wheatgrass, at an elevation of 5250 feet.  (Colors are for dry soil unless otherwise noted)
A--0 to 1 inches; reddish brown (2.5YR 4/4) silt loam, dark reddish brown (5YR 3/4) moist; weak very fine and fine platy structure; moderately hard, friable, nonsticky and nonplastic; few fine roots; few very fine and common fine pores; about 10 percent calcium carbonate equivalent; very slightly effervescent; slightly alkaline (pH 7.8); gradual wavy boundary. (1 to 2 inches thick)
Bw--1 to 9 inches; reddish brown (5YR 4/4) loam, dark reddish brown (5YR 3/4) moist; moderate medium subangular blocky structure; hard, friable, slightly sticky and moderately plastic; very few very fine roots; common fine pores; about 13 percent calcium carbonate equivalent; strongly effervescent; slightly alkaline (pH 7.8); gradual wavy boundary. (3 to 10 inches thick)
Bk1--9 to 25 inches; yellowish red (5YR 5/6) loam, yellowish red (5YR 4/6) moist; moderate medium subangular blocky structure; hard, friable, slightly sticky and slightly plastic; very few very fine roots; few very fine pores; about 18 percent calcium carbonate equivalent; strongly effervescent; strongly alkaline (pH 8.6); gradual wavy boundary. (7 to 25 inches thick)
Bk2--25 to 39 inches; reddish yellow (5YR 6/6) very fine sandy loam, yellowish red (5YR 4/6) moist; moderate medium subangular blocky structure; very hard, very friable, non-sticky and non-plastic; very few very fine and coarse roots; very few very fine pores; about 10 percent gravel; carbonates disseminated and as pendants on the undersides of some gravel fragments; about 13 percent calcium carbonate equivalent;violently effervescent; strongly alkaline (pH 8.5); gradual wavy boundary.
BCk--39 to 51 inches; yellowish red (5YR 4/6) very fine sandy loam, red (2.5YR 4/6) moist; weak medium subangular blocky structure; hard, very friable, nonsticky and nonplastic; about 10 percent gravel; carbonates disseminated and as pendants on the undersides of some gravel fragments; about 10 percent calcium carbonate equivalent;violently effervescent; moderately alkaline (pH 8.4); gradual wavy boundary.  (Combined Bk2 and BCk horizons 15 to 44 inches thick)
Cr--51 to 60 inches; soft, red calcareous sandstone.

TYPE LOCATION.content: TYPE LOCATION: Johnson County, Wyoming; About 2,110 feet north and 170 feet west southeast corner of Section 2, T.47 N., R83 W.; lat. 44 degrees 4 minutes 8 seconds N. and long. 106 degrees 47 minutes 34 seconds W., NAD 1983.  Robinson Canyon NE USGS topographic quadrangle.

RANGE IN CHARACTERISTICS.content:
RANGE IN CHARACTERISTICS:
Mean annual soil temperature: 44 to 47 degrees F.
Depth to paralithic contact: 40 to 60 inches to sandstone.
Depth secondary calcium carbonates: 4 to 12 inches.
Particle-size control section (weighted average):
Clay content: 12 to 18 percent.
Rock Fragments: 0 to 15 percent gravels.
A horizon:
Hue: 2.5YR or 5YR
Value: 4 or 5 dry; 3 or 4 moist
Chroma:  3 to 6
Texture: silt loam
Clay content:  18 to 26 percent
Rock Fragments: 0 to 5 percent
Calcium carbonate equivalent: 9 to 12 percent
Reaction: slightly alkaline or moderately alkaline
Bw horizon:
Hue: 5YR or 2.5YR
Value: 4 or 5 dry; 3 or 4 moist
Chroma: 4 to 6
Texture: loam or silt loam
Clay content:  18 to 26 percent
Rock Fragments: 0 to 2 percent
Calcium carbonate equivalent: 9 to 14 percent
Reaction: slightly alkaline or moderately alkaline
Bk and BCk horizons:
Hue: 5YR or 2.5YR
Value: 4 to 6 dry; 4 or 5 moist
Chroma: 4 to 6
Texture: loam, silt loam or very fine sandy loam
Clay content:  10 to 18 percent
Rock Fragments: 0 to 25
Calcium carbonate equivalent: 5 to 18 percent
Reaction:  slightly alkaline to strongly alkaline

COMPETING SERIES.content:
COMPETING SERIES:  These are the Amesha, Kalsted and Lakebench series.
Amesha: hues of 7.5YR or yellower.
Kalsted: has hues of 10YR or yellower.
Lakebench: does not have a paralithic contact above a depth of 60 inches.

GEOGRAPHIC SETTING.content:
GEOGRAPHIC SETTING:
Parent material:  alluvium derived from red calcareous sandstone
Landform: valley
Slopes: 3 to 15 percent
Elevation:  5200 to 5500 feet
Mean annual air temperature:  42 to 45 degrees F.
Mean annual precipitation:  15 to 19 inches.
Frost-free period: 70 to 105 days.

GEOGRAPHICALLY ASSOCIATED SOILS.content:
GEOGRAPHICALLY ASSOCIATED SOILS:  These are the Skelridge, Bloodstone, Riedel, Abac (dry phase) and Fetterman series.
Fetterman soils are on backslopes of scarps and hogbacks; have a paralithic contact between 20 and 40 inches.
Abac (dry phase) soils are on backslopes of scarps and hogbacks; have a paralithic contact within 20 inches.
Riedel soils are on gently sloping to steep sedimentary uplands; have a paralithic contact between 20 and 40 inches.  Bloodstone soils are on backslopes of scarps and hogbacks; have a lithic contact within 20 inches.
Skelridge soils are on backslopes and shoulders of high hills and backslopes of scarps and hogbacks; have a paralithic contact between 20 and 40 inches.

DRAINAGE AND PERMEABILITY.content: DRAINAGE AND SATURATED HYDRAULIC CONDUCTIVITY: Well drained; low to medium runoff; moderately high saturated hydraulic conductivity.

USE AND VEGETATION.content: USE AND VEGETATION: These soils are used for irrigated and dryland grain production and rangeland. The potential native vegetation is crested wheatgrass, fringe sage, and western wheatgrass.

DISTRIBUTION AND EXTENT.content: DISTRIBUTION AND EXTENT: Redbull soils are of small extent in northeastern Wyoming.

REGIONAL OFFICE.section: MLRA SOIL SURVEY REGIONAL OFFICE (MO) RESPONSIBLE
REGIONAL OFFICE.content: MLRA SOIL SURVEY REGIONAL OFFICE (MO) RESPONSIBLE: Denver, Colorado

ORIGIN.content: SERIES PROPOSED: Johnson County (Northern Johnson Area), Wyoming, 2005.

REMARKS.content:
REMARKS:  The soil is tentatively classified as coarse-loamy, pending lab results.
Diagnostic horizons and features recognized in this pedon are:
Particle-size control section:  The zone from 10 to 40 inches (Bk1, Bk2, BCk horizons)
Ochric epipedon:  The zone from the 0 to 1 inch (A horizon)
Calcic horizon:  The zone from 9 to 51 inches (Bk1, Bk2, BCk horizons)
Paralithic contact: 51 inches (top of Cr horizon)
Taxonomic Version:  Ninth edition to the Keys to Soil Taxonomy, 2003.
